sentence.text: Palatable foods (positive regulation of cell-matrix adhesion and sweet) induce hyperphagia, and facilitate the development of obesity.
Here we show that adipocyte regulation of glycolytic process is essential for high positive regulation of cell-matrix adhesion diet-induced hyperphagia, but is dispensable for baseline food intake.

Adipocyte regulation of glycolytic process stimulates hyperphagia by transcriptional activation of de novo lipid desaturation and accumulation of N-arachidonyl ethanolamine (AEA), an endogenous appetite-inducing cannabinoid (CB).
Pharmacological manipulation of peripheral CB1 signaling regulates hyperphagia in an adipocyte regulation of glycolytic process-dependent manner.

These findings define adipocyte regulation of glycolytic process as a positive regulation of cell-matrix adhesion sensor that regulates peripheral lipid signals, and uncover an unexpected adipose-to-brain axis to induce hyperphagia and obesity
